_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
The City of Sacramento Department of Utilities (City) has been requested by the cognizant Administering Agency, Sacramento County Environmental Management Department, Hazardous Materials Division (HMD), to institute a Risk Management Program and file a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for their Sacramento River Water Treatment Plant, which contains chlorine, classified as a Regulated Substance (RS).  This request was made in March 1997 pursuant to California Health & Safety Code (H&SC) Division 20, Chapter 6.95, Article 2, Section 25534(b)(1) and California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP).  As required by Federal Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Program regulations at 40 CFR Part 68, an RMP for this plant has been filed with USEPA.
This Risk Management Plan identifies the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with Regulated Substances (RS¿s) handled at this facility in excess of California threshold quantities; describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to assess possible effects on employees and offsite public and environmental receptors; provides the results of an offsite consequences analysis; defines a prevention program, emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of accidental releases of RS¿s; and establishes a schedule and responsibilities for implementation of mitigation measures and auditing of program elements.  
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
It is the policy of the City that the receipt, storage and handling of chlorine at its facilities be done in a manner which meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of releases of chlorine to the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.  In order to accomplish this goal, the City has gathe

red safety information on chlorine and on the process, equipment and procedures involving chlorine; performed a structured assessment of hazards of the process and external events which might affect the process; performed an offsite consequences analysis of defined release scenarios; established a written program for prevention and mitigation of releases; and established a written emergency response program coordinated with emergency response agencies.
Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
The City owns and operates numerous water production wells, a 3 million gallon reservoir, and two water treatment plants, in Sacramento County which use chlorine.  The RS used at the the Sacramento River Water Treatment Plant and considered in this RMP is chlorine.
General Accident Release Prevention Programs
General accident release prevention programs instituted by the City are categorized as administrative (management) programs; procedures, training, and engineering controls; and emergency response programs.  The City maintains a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, and numerous other elements meeting CalARP and CalOSHA standards.
Chemical-Specific Release Prevention Steps
Release prevention steps specific to chlorine have been identified and implemented.  These include, among other items, installing vacuum regulators on the container gas valves thus eliminating the pressurized portion of the system, installing a leak scrubber, and installing automatic-closing valve operators on the ton containers.
Five Year Accident History
There have been no accidents involving chlorine at the Sacramento River Water Treatment Plant within the past five years meeting the criteria stated in the CalARP regulations.
Emergency Response Program
The City¿s Emergency response program applicable to chlorine consists of First Response to hazardous materials release emergencies in accordance with a written Emergency Response procedure.  Personnel assigned as First Responders all have cu

rrent HAZWOPER certifications and personal protective equipment training and fit testing.  The chlorine emergency response program has been coordinated with Sacramento County HMD.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazard analyses and program audits which the City committed to accomplish have been completed.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of Process Hazard Analyses, Management of Change reviews, and audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.
